Posts.Content: Hi all, I had a double mastectomy and auxiliary node dissection 7 weeks ago, I still have a very stiff shoulder on the right side (where nodes were removed) and my ribs are very tender to touch. Was just wondering if this type of pain/stiffness was normal after node removal?  It's not enough to take painkillers but is worse in the eve? Jen
Posts.Title: Rib pain after mastectomy

Posts.Content: Hi! Ah thank you! Yep today it's more a bruised feeling! And snap to mind in overdrive!! I remember the same pain immediately after the op and am definitely getting more feeling back everywhere which includes lots of different aches and  pains - I should be grateful for the feeling back but can't help fear the worst! I've a check next week before my chemo starts so will mention it then too Jen xxx
Posts.Title: Rib pain after mastectomy

Posts.Content: Yes definitely when I reach up high- which being 5'0 is ALOT... Must move the wine glasses to a lower shelf....  it seems to come and go- today is worse but then I've been really active (for me) this weekend chasing my 1 year old. I'll blame him not the outback of reach wine glasses Xxx
Posts.Title: Rib pain after mastectomy

Posts.Content: I've been really lucky with side effects- I've had 3X EC and was fine- a lot of early nights but no nausea etc? They have lots of things to combat the effects too which is great. Just had my first T cycle and am quite achey but again al manageable?  My little girl is also fine with "baldy mummy"! We got some pink wigs for her and I told her that the medicine made it fall it but will grow back and she hasn't batted an eyelid, in fact she keeps outing me and demanding I show everyone my baldy head!!!  I think the actual fact of having a 1 and 3 yr old means we are in a good position to cope with the fatigue!  I got both vaccinated for chicken pox which you are entitled to in the NHS too Jen xxxx
Posts.Title: Masectomy

Posts.Content: I went into hospital fri morning and was home having a roast by Sunday lunchtime!  Took painkillers every 4 hours which kept me mostly pain free. I had drains for 2 weeks - I think my surgeon doesn't like to rush them... but I got little bags to carry them in and told my daughter they were full of calpol!  My 9 month old decided to crawl for the first time the day I came home just to really put me through my paces!  It was honestly all manageable as is the chemo, I've a great support system thankfully but I've kept all our little gangs routines and play dates.  Now I have a comparison I honestly think chemo is easier than a tired teething toddler any day xxx
Posts.Title: Masectomy

Posts.Content: Hi, I have a 1 and 3 year old too!  had double mastectomy and implant recon in Jan and now having chemo. I had help the first 2 weeks after the op but it was all very very doable. My little boy was 9 months and crawling! Could still cuddle, play etc and I think I probably drove about 3/4 weeks after.  I was in softplay week 2! Any questions feel free to message me.  Jen xxxx
Posts.Title: Masectomy

Posts.Content: Hey there, I'm so so sorry you are finding yourself in this position especially when you should be enjoying your little one and the sunshine. Just wanted to say that I was diagnosed when my little boy was 8 months old (have a 3 yr old also). I'm coming out the other side now and have just started radiotherapy after a double MX and 6 cycles of chemo and if I can offer any assurance or answer any questions please don't hesitate to ask. In all honesty everything was doable and I have not once wished this time away- we've have a fab summer so far without this pesky cancer stopping us and so can you, you can and will do this xxxxx
Posts.Title: Waiting for biopsy results - breast cancer

Posts.Content: Oh ladies! It's just so horrible for you both. Waiting in limbo waiting for your results is rubbish,  but I honestly felt so much better when we got the plan of action in place and the ball rolling- I think it gives you some control back? i had an enlarged lymph node too that they biopsied but came back clear. I had no symptoms- I'm 37 also and had yearly MRI due to family genetics and history so I feel incredibly lucky. Mine was grade 3 multifocal- 9mm, 3mm and 5mm but they treated as a 5cm area of "at risk of cancer" so with that and my age etc I got the full works! I was worried about the aggressiveness etc due to our age but as my lovely Mac nurse says- while it goes against us a little , it also goes for us in the sense that we get all treatments available.   The hair thing.... actually the most liberating bit! Mine fell out first cycle so myself and stroppy 3 yr old played hairdressers and shaved it! I've more compliments bald than with hair!!! But you also have options such as the cold cap with I'm sure some ladies on here will tell you about. i had my eyebrows tattooed before chemo- best thing I did and I can get ready in seconds- handy with feral 1 yr old...  Of course I've  had some down days but I've also had some brilliant ones- the treatments are doable- there is a wide range of things to help side effects and some gorgeous complimentary treatments you can have to feel a bit pampered at some Macmillan centres.  I'm not exactly fighting fit- more slummymummy than yummy and I'm managing (with help and love) ok?  In regards to the size of your lump- you've just made a gorgeous human so there will be a number of explanations as to the size that may not be related? I had some cysts and blocked ducts going on too when I was diagnosed. i started to take a pen and pad to appointments- mum brain and chemo brain is hysterical so write it down and any questions you want to ask- I was forever bursting back in having forgotten to ask stuff!
Posts.Title: Waiting for biopsy results - breast cancer

Posts.Content: Oh no!!! Shingles was bad enough when I had it at 17!! Although I am slightly less dramatic these days I do remember it's knocking me out for 2 weeks....
Posts.Title: Chickenpox and chemo

Posts.Content: Hi,  Don't know if this helps but because you are having chemo your daughter is entitled to the chicken pox vaccine free on the NHS? It's on their website- I got my 1 and 3 yr old vaccinated last month. The receptionist denied all knowledge a first however I asked for a Doctor to call me and they confirmed and ordered the vaccines for me. It's a live vaccine so best to triple check with your doctor. My two were fine- no side effect and now we don't have to worry at nursery as there are lots of cases.  I got all the info on the NHS chicken pox website. Good luck with chemo- I'm halfway through- it's all very doable and Goes surprisingly quick!!! Jen xxxx
Posts.Title: Chickenpox and chemo

Posts.Content: My doctors receptionist tried to tell me that I had to pay and that they didn't do the vaccine- I ended up requesting a doctor to call me back who then actually checked properly and ordered it to the surgery so don't be fobbed off! This receptionist also told me I didn't qualify for the flu jab.......  it's definitely nice not to worry every time there's an outbreak at nursery or when we  go to a soft play or farm etc..  Jen xxxx
Posts.Title: Chickenpox and chemo

Posts.Content: Hey lovelies,  Has anyone experienced a cough as a side effect? On day 4 of my first Doxetaxol cycle and have been coughing from the moment I left the chemo unit?? No temp or cold etc?  Jen xxx
Posts.Title: *** May 2018 Breast Cancer Chemo Club ***

Posts.Content: Ah thank you!  These T cycles are a bit vicious! Think I had it lovely and easy with the EC...  jen xxx
Posts.Title: *** May 2018 Breast Cancer Chemo Club ***

Posts.Content: Ah congratulations!!!!! Amazing!!  Know what you mean about the worrying! Chuffed you've finished! X
Posts.Title: *** May 2018 Breast Cancer Chemo Club ***
